positive.review:
Mount & Blade: Warband is an absolute gem of a game for anyone who loves strategy, action, and immersive medieval warfare. The game offers a level of freedom and depth that is rarely seen in other titles, and it‚Äôs easy to lose yourself in its expansive world.

First, let‚Äôs talk about the army building. One of the standout features of Warband is how deeply satisfying the process of raising and commanding an army can be. The game allows you to recruit a variety of troops from different factions, train them up, and strategically manage your forces in ways that feel incredibly rewarding. Watching your humble band of ragtag soldiers evolve into a mighty war machine is an experience unlike any other. Plus, you can customize your army‚Äôs composition, making every battle feel fresh and unique. The system of managing morale, equipment, and positioning adds layers of strategy that keep you constantly engaged.

The siege warfare in Warband is equally impressive. Whether you‚Äôre attacking a heavily fortified castle or defending one of your own, the siege mechanics are thrilling. You‚Äôll find yourself leading massive assaults, scaling walls with ladders, or even using siege weapons like trebuchets and catapults to break down the defenses. The atmosphere during these massive battles is tense and exhilarating, and the feeling of charging up a hill with your army or watching the castle gates crumble is truly epic.

What really ties everything together, though, is the experience of supporting an existing clan or creating your own. Whether you decide to join one of the game‚Äôs established factions or strike out on your own to form your own clan, the political and strategic elements add so much depth to the experience. If you go the clan route, there‚Äôs a fantastic sense of progression as you build your reputation, forge alliances, and claim territory. The relationships you build with other leaders and factions are dynamic, with every decision impacting your rise to power. If you manage to take control of a kingdom, you‚Äôll get to experience the thrill of not just leading armies but also managing your lands, making decisions that affect the growth of your realm.

Overall, Mount & Blade: Warband is one of those rare games that gives players a true sense of freedom and impact. Whether you‚Äôre building the perfect army, storming castles, or shaping the future of a kingdom, every moment feels like a meaningful part of a larger story. It‚Äôs a must-play for anyone who enjoys tactical combat, medieval settings, or just a game that lets you carve your own path.

Gotta love this game absolute classic. As you can tell it hasn't aged too well, the animations are stiff and feel odd and the textures aren't great either. Audio sounds pretty average for it's age too. That being said, the rest of the game is amazing. The core gameplay itself is quite repetitive kill, loot sell and recruit. But that's all it needs to make it work and work well it does. Quests are terrible but what do you expect from a game this old... The modding community is amazing, making mods for almost every universe you could think of. I've put hundreds of hours into GOT Persino and Warhammer mods each time I play I love it, they are what make this game what it is. Multiplayer is still active too with thousands of people playing all the time. I recommend getting Warband and it's dlc and giving it a go.

Warband is still the best Mount & Blade game. It lacks some quality of life features found in Bannerlord, but makes up for it with much better balance, mechanics, and personality. And in spite of its age, the actual combat feels a lot sharper. There's a lot less ambiguity in your movements and attacks compared to Bannerlord, and the lances in particular feel a lot more usable. The wide variety of excellent mods is icing on the cake.

Someday Bannerlord might overtake Warband. Not today.

After 1,000 Hours Playing Warband, It is the greatest game i have ever played during my childhood.
Only 2nd To Stronghold Crusaders II
Highly Recommend Playing and experience it.
10/10 Replayablility
10/10 Gameplay
10/10 Overall
For basically a game thats 20 years old its still really enjoyable to play.
You wont ever regret buying this game, Its graphics are simple so if you have a potato you wont have a problem.

This game is my go to game! there is nothing you cannot do! not only does it combine 4x stategy, but it also puts you into the full scale battle! You will have to manage troops, skills, resources morale and more! even more so the modding scene is unmatched. everything from star wars to lord of the rings to roman history to world war 2! The possibilities are endless! My 500 hours is on this device alone, i have around the same amount of time played on counsel and around a quarter of that played on another account! Only thing to keep in mind is that this game does not hold hands at all, there is no tutorial or campaign. in the beginning there is a small questline to get the player started with some money and equipment, but other than that it is a full on sandbox style game whatever you choose to do whenever you want!

This is the first Warband game with this company, and I love it to death.  There are plenty of mods out there for it, including two mods I designed and programmed myself.  The action never grows old, the fights are epic, and siege warfare is the best.  ALSO, there is no active first person sneaking or stealth in this wonderful game, which I hate.  You can always send a companion to sneak in somewhere, leaving me the heck out of it, LOL.  

In the end, with proper planning, battles and careful subterfuge, you can eventually rule the world.  Once you do a legit playthrough with vanilla and rule the world, then I advise cheating with the console and mods,.  It's enjoyable and worth the time, even for an older game with ugly models.  It still looks awesome as all get out when you use your bow to snipe a guy on a castle wall, he grabs his face and screams while dying.  

Epic.  Fun.  Everything you enjoy about combat based games.  I never did multiplayer, as I am a proud lone wolf.  If I take over the world, it's all on me!  Yeah!

I may have a lot of mixed feelings about the game after 500 hours, but it certainly is one of a kind. Kudos to taleworlds for crafting such a great game and embracing a legendary modding community. Yes, do play the mods of Warband. It's the soul of the game and what makes this game some of the most replayable games of all time. And if you haven't inferred, probably more than 90% of playtime here were on mods, so account for the bias here (in my defense, I got bored with the vanilla game quick, but holy shoot, the mods were what made me hooked and caused me to decote so many hours in)

Great combat. Swinging the mouse/sword just feels rewarding. Commanding units on the field is fun. No reason to play base game - great mods exist and have solved most of the bad stuff. Graphics are old, but the game loads really fast. Our brains dream the visuals to be better and stories help in immersion.

Basically ive play this game to death, and what that means is that if i ever decide to reinstall it again, i will fire it up, hear the menu music, start a character, get into the game, get to the world map and alt-f4.

But dont get me wrong, its a good game, its just that ive spent almost 300 hours in it (on steam alone, more before i got it on steam), and some people will spend many many many many many more hours in this game. It might just be the perfect game for you to spend 10.000 hours in.
But me personally, i'm done, besides, Bannerlord is out, and it does everything this game does, but better and more.

Of course with modern hardware you can crank up armies on the field to the max with ease, and it is a lot of fun to see two big armies fight eachother and that has always been the main appeal with the 'Mount & Blade' games, but there is more to do and you dont even have to stick to the rules, you can RP as a coastal raider if you want for a thousand hours, or you can conquer the world in 7 days. the possibilites are nearly endless.

My enjoyment score at its peak was 91%

Fav quote: "Thats a nice head you have on your shoulders"
A classic it gave me so much joy I remeber playing it when I was younger and even if it is by any means perfect this game has a special place in my heart
Best game ever. Even has its own linux distribution and can install trollgame patch to it on linux :D
Good, fun, enjoyable but mostly held by mods.

I played a stupid amount of this game before ever buying it on steam, and I feel like buying it again was an incredibly worthwhile choice. The base game alone is worth a lot of investment, but definitely check out any cool sounding mod! Your mind will thank you, even if your time-management skills do not lol!!
one of the best games ever made and it has so many mods. this is still better than bannerlord by a mile

[h1]‚öîÔ∏è Mount & Blade: Warband ‚öîÔ∏è[/h1]

This game had me hooked for a while, and I still revisit it from time to time in its more modern form, Bannerlord. Mount & Blade: Warband surprised me with its historical-fiction setting, offering a deep world where the player can truly interact and influence everything from politics to warfare.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]‚ú® The Great [/h2]

[list]
[*][b]Unique Gameplay[/b] ‚Äì A strategy game experienced in first-person as a captain, letting you directly influence politics and battles.  
[*][b]Diplomacy & Strategy[/b] ‚Äì Politics, alliances, and negotiation are well-crafted and deeply integrated; it‚Äôs genuinely fun to play with.  
[*][b]Battles[/b] ‚Äì Massive and demanding, keeping you alert to manage troops while keeping your own health and role in check.  
[*][b]Gender Dynamics[/b] ‚Äì Playing as male or female significantly changes diplomacy and life outcomes, offering a hands-on experience of inequality and social roles.  
[*][b]Immersive Setting[/b] ‚Äì The world feels alive, and the atmosphere is top-notch.
[/list]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]‚ö†Ô∏è The Not So Great [/h2]

[list]
[*][b]Music & Sound[/b] ‚Äì Practically nonexistent outside the title screen, and some in-game sounds feel out of place; likely a technical limitation of 2010.  
[*][b]AI Patterns[/b] ‚Äì After many hours, the AI starts to show predictable patterns, reducing the feeling of difficulty.  
[*][b]Complex Lore[/b] ‚Äì The depth of the world is incredible, but it can be challenging to fully grasp at first.
[/list]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]üí¨ Verdict [/h2]

Mount & Blade: Warband is a rare gem that mixes strategy, politics, and first-person combat in a way few games manage. It‚Äôs deep, challenging, and immersive, and even after years it still holds up as a game that rewards curiosity and experimentation.
It's not about the end, it's about the journey. I wish I could take over the continent without it bugging out and not giving me the victory even with everything conquered.

I fell in love with this game when it came out on game pass and now that I play it on PC I could easily sink another 100 hours in to it. It has all the polish of a sandwich and it's as simple too. You'll understand the basics in as little as an hour and even though the combat can be clunky sometimes doesn't mean it's not satisfying (especially on horse back swinging into a mass of enemies). Also this is undoubtedly the most open ended RPG I have ever played. After the first mission you will be completely free to do whatever you want and it will not hold your hand while you are doing it. You can play as a general in an army, a mercenary, a robber baron, a business mogul, an arena fighter, and even a kingdom toppling conqueror. You can ransom lords, sell captives into slavery, rustle cattle, build a massive army or just a small band of companions. You can be a hero, save villages, rescue people, hunt down marauders, rise from a peasant to a noble in so many ways. Yes the graphics are highly dated, yes the missions and dialogue are repetitive, but like a sandwich you can make anything out of it and that is why I would highly recommend this game to anyone who just wants to be free in a medieval RPG.
low running requirements, amazing mods, amazing game stock. 10/10 been playing for a large portion of my life now. Love the mechanics and commanding aspect.
A cult classic. Vanilla is great, mods make it fantastic
Good combination of action and strategy gameplay  rolled into one. The mods community makes this into a whole new game for so many experienced players.

Classic must play video game, reminds me of an old web browser game i would play after school, except this was made by a video game company and is more fleshed out.

Definitely give this one a shot over the newer one that came out.

classic. a one of its kind sandbox rpg where you can lead huge armies. 

Mechanics are a bit in depth and its a little bloated some times... But it's great.

I first played Warband years ago in 2018 on PS4 and been in love with it ever since. The game has a certain charm to it, and gives player total freedom on how you play. The modding community is one of the best aspects of this game. With mods such as The Last Days of the Third Age, Prophesy of Pendor, A World of Fire and Ice, and Bellum Imperii to name a few off my top picks. I have over 1000 hours in the game, and I can easily see myself playing another 1000.

Mount & Blade: Warband is one of those rare games that feels truly alive. I grew up with it, and even after all these years, there‚Äôs nothing quite like it. From humble beginnings as a lone wanderer to commanding your own army and carving out a kingdom, every moment feels earned. It‚Äôs the kind of game that pulls you in for ‚Äújust one more battle‚Äù ‚Äî and suddenly, it‚Äôs 3 a.m.

What makes Warband so timeless is its freedom. You can be a mercenary, a trader, a rebel, or a ruler ‚Äî and the world always reacts to you. The combat, though, is where it truly shines. It‚Äôs raw, physical, and deeply immersive ‚Äî not about flashy combos, but about timing, positioning, and the weight of every swing. Every clash of steel feels personal, every victory hard-fought. Whether you‚Äôre leading cavalry across open fields or holding the line in a desperate siege, it never loses its intensity.

The music deserves its own mention ‚Äî that bold, medieval soundtrack that somehow makes even a desperate skirmish feel legendary. It captures the soul of Warband perfectly: grand, a little rough around the edges, but full of heart. Every drumbeat and lute string feels like home to anyone who‚Äôs spent time in Calradia.

Even with all the newer games that came after, Mount & Blade: Warband remains unmatched in spirit. It‚Äôs not just a medieval sandbox ‚Äî it‚Äôs a journey, a memory, and a world that still calls you back years later. ‚öîÔ∏è

I could pick potato GladOs, stick her to a screen, and be able to run this game alongside her clapping functionality.
And over the years, that was pretty much what has happened to me. Even if one year I was stuck with a bad computer, this game would always stay with me, and as we were talking about an Elder Scrolls entry, the mods where always there to shake and add things. It is a very archaic game, very fundamentalist, very functional with the least moving parts posible. And that's the reason why this game is inmortal. Never gets old to start a new game and roleplay as something different, somewhere else. There are bugs, and the AI not being very smart a lot of the times, but the core fundamentals are all here, and looking at other meddieval life simulators such as KCD, and see its bugs and AI, I think that MaB:W still has an edge till this day. Very worhty of its on sale price.

This game is incredibly fun and rewarding to play. Focus on buttering up to the king, marry into the family or whatever, and you should quickly get knighted and get a village to manage, which is a whole new set of systems. Managing that well and/or pursuing trading can get you the cash needed to set up businesses in cities, which as far as ive seen is the best way to get a really solid cashflow and start pursuing bigger things.

Love going around the realm of Calradia or playing the Star Wars mod, good gameplay, a little difficult to get into at first but it gets easier the more you go along and learn how everything works.  Nothing to really complain about here honestly.

Game refuses to launch. Steam says the game is running. Task manager shows it's background processes running. Screen and taskbar show absolutely nothing. Complete waste of time. Not only does the game refuse to launch, it refuses to close as well requiring a system restart to stop the game from hold your PC hostage. Avoid like the plague.

Mount & Blade: Warband is not a bad video game. For a certain type of person who enjoys this wargaming genre, it might be one of the best games ever made. Yet, I find it hard to recommend. It's not so much that some graphics have aged, as the game still looks pretty good. For a game with this much text, I think they could've spent a little bit more time making it readable and well-aligned, but I don't think that's a fatal flaw either. 

Rather, I just find that there isn't that much detail worth thinking about. Lords, cities, the shape of the continent, your companions and more are so generic they might as well be randomly generated. There are a handful of quests which I can almost see how they were programmed in my head. Battles degenerate into swinging around the enemy and attacking from the back or just spamming your attack. The whole game has a feeling of being a fisher-price version of what it wants to be.

Another thing lowering my opinion on the game is its cost. Right now Warband is going for $19.99, despite being over 15 years old. Of course, you can wait for it to go on sale, but for a game this old it's probably about time to permanently drop the price so the developers can go below the 90% sale limit. 

So I can't recommend it. Maybe if you get it for 2$ on a huge sale and you don't really value your time very much, or if this type of game is really your thing you'll love it, otherwise it's kinda forgettable.

Played both Warband and Bannerlord.
In this game you will see 90%-95% of the content from Bannerlord, but with less bugs, less grind and less frustration.
You can jump from 150 to 500 battle size limit by changing the config file.

In the Bannerlord there is only one "good" feature, it is when you can call other lords from the distance to join your party for influence, but unfortunately even this important feature does not work well in the sequel(lords getting captured on the way or losing whole their army because of starving on the way to you).

Anyway this game is still lucks Quality of life features, has a lot of micromanagement in the UI, quests is just boring, repetitive and what I really hate is how you pushed to do that quests because you need to build relationships with lords which will take you weeks or months of playing. Without building relationships you are not able to progress the game further, but this mechanic really sucks. Oh, you even need to build relationships with f*cking villages, because in other case they will not give higher grade troops.

 [strike]I will give this game thumb up only because of it's age and innovativeness for it's times.  [/strike]
Sorry, I changed my mind. Never play this game if you don't have at least 8 hour per each day, or find some mods that optimize your time significantly.

The term game over can apply.  hitting a game over and the company tries to get you to keep playing. stupid

I like the gameplay but the game is too spread out with it's objectives. If it was more linear, I would recommend it more to others but since it isn't, then no, maybe if you like Open World games then go for it.

I cannot believe i let myself listen to the reviews that just say "This game is the greatest!" without giving context. This game was horrible from start to finish. First off, its one of those games where you can pick a bunch of options from the start, and you are told to create your own story. What you are not told is that there is only one viable option, and its option 1, for everything. every choice after one is there to pad play time so they can say their game has tons of options. the first character i made started in an area that was way to difficult to do, given i had just downloaded the game. nothing told me that. nothing said, hey, these options are for people who have beat the game already, and want the variety of losing to spice things up. so my first character was a scratch, which you know, no one is ever attached to their first character right? yeah... so once i had done exactly what the developers had wanted, and picked option 1 for everything, and couldn't have cared less about my character (way to go getting me investing in the game...) i started again in the easy area. the first few quests barely set my character up, and the starving peasants that were the only option for me to hire at my current finance level were garbage at fighting. the only option that seemed available to me was to go around and hire as many sickly peasants as i could. those of course dried up very quickly, and i ended up with only 59 men. I did also attempt a tournament, which was awful. The weapons were random, and for several i was given a lance. the lance only does decent (if any) damage at speed, however, the enemies would of course chase me, so i could only slow down and turn to try and hit them, which did no damage. after loading my save 3 times, and running in circles for 10 mins, i finally managed to beat the tournament. my winnings were not even enough to buy a decent weapon or horse. after the tournament, i was bored of skulking around in the shadows and tried getting close to the border. I was immediately charged by 70 horsemen and defeated in battle. i alt f4-ed out and started my review. i have also noticed that people are saying mods make the game great. I am sure after someone has changed core things about the game, and added in things for fun, that this game is good. but take note developers, you did not make a good game, the modding community did after fixing your hot garbage. if i can get a refund after the time it took me to get through the start of this game i will be very happy, as the sale price of $6.50 was too much to waste. If i cannot get my refund, i may attempt to play it after modding it and making it into a game that is fun to play.

terrible combat where soldiers can hit through eachother, its just a spam fest where you spam the best soldiers and win, theres no more to it than that

you can kite enemies while being on horseback and get them to run in circles trying to attack you, signs of incredibly poor ai right there, everything reacts the same to you, so it makes everything very repetitive and dull, but its not like anyone cares about basic stuff like that, since youre having so much fun after all, beating braindead ai

you rush up to them with a giant horse, very heavy mind you, charge and then do no damage, so fun, very realistic and appropriate for the time, or you go fighting them on horseback and witness as every soldier has perfect tracking, and can block, and perfectly parry a gigantic heavy plate armoured horse charging straight at them with a lance, the signs of a great combat system start with every enemy having perfect tracking, this compounds on the issue of being able to attack through eachother, by the way (i know you cant attack through eachother, but the weapon length and hitbox allows for it, so it might aswell be allowed)

taking over castles requires no tactic, starving the castle takes too long to be useful, you mush 100+ heavy infantry up a single ladder or a siege tower and hopefully push through a weak braindead garrison, or not, then if youre lucky, spend the next 10 minutes trying to reach some random enemy your soldiers just ganged up on, not being able to attack him because theyre all jampacked together in one giant sausage party

battle advantage is arbitrary, does it effect your own soldiers hit rate? i dont know, but they seem more ineffective than usual when the advantage is in the negatives, does that make any sense?

you have terrain, movement speed being affected by these and it doesnt matter, because my battle advantage is low? so my archers hit less often because of low battle advantage, even while firing at troops and cavalries moving slowly up a mountain? moving slowly and predictably in a braindead AI fashion? and my spear units suddenly find it harder to kill cavalry, walking up to them with no momentum?

but i dont know what battle advantage does, so whatever, it is still arbitrary, and does not take into consideration of anything but character traits, it should be removed, in my opinion

i believe anyone who has played this for 1k hours+ are autistic, or dumb and maybe both at the same time, as multiplayer is no better, playing as an archer is better than playing as a knight in my opinion, constantly headshotting people as they climb up to you has its clear advantage, truly degenerate

the only fun mod i had was PARADIGM WORLD, which is an ultra spam fest on steroid,  where you can create your own unit using prisoners equipment, in the form of some sort of synthesis mechanic, where you squeeze 15 prisoners of a type, into your custom unit to get them to use the equipment, you can create very powerful units this way, so it was atleast satisfying to play the game then, having real rewards for time invested

but other than that, it was still braindead, with braindead AI, so not much different, but atleast everything is more fast paced and fun in that one, is it rather cathartic killing 200 guys with your ultra powerful light sword
feels like an alpha version, every system is shallow and emtly
no real non fag would play this game
broken
lol.

Mount & Blade: Warband is not a bad video game. For a certain type of person who enjoys this wargaming genre, it might be one of the best games ever made. Yet, I find it hard to recommend. It's not so much that some graphics have aged, as the game still looks pretty good. For a game with this much text, I think they could've spent a little bit more time making it readable and well-aligned, but I don't think that's a fatal flaw either. 

Rather, I just find that there isn't that much detail worth thinking about. Lords, cities, the shape of the continent, your companions and more are so generic they might as well be randomly generated. There are a handful of quests which I can almost see how they were programmed in my head. Battles degenerate into swinging around the enemy and attacking from the back or just spamming your attack. The whole game has a feeling of being a fisher-price version of what it wants to be.

Another thing lowering my opinion on the game is its cost. Right now Warband is going for $19.99, despite being over 15 years old. Of course, you can wait for it to go on sale, but for a game this old it's probably about time to permanently drop the price so the developers can go below the 90% sale limit. 

So I can't recommend it. Maybe if you get it for 2$ on a huge sale and you don't really value your time very much, or if this type of game is really your thing you'll love it, otherwise it's kinda forgettable.

You can jump from 150 to 500 battle size limit by changing the config file.

In the Bannerlord there is only one "good" feature, it is when you can call other lords from the distance to join your party for influence, but unfortunately even this important feature does not work well in the sequel(lords getting captured on the way or losing whole their army because of starving on the way to you).

Anyway this game is still lucks Quality of life features, has a lot of micromanagement in the UI, quests is just boring, repetitive and what I really hate is how you pushed to do that quests because you need to build relationships with lords which will take you weeks or months of playing. Without building relationships you are not able to progress the game further, but this mechanic really sucks. Oh, you even need to build relationships with f*cking villages, because in other case they will not give higher grade troops.

 [strike]I will give this game thumb up only because of it's age and innovativeness for it's times.  [/strike]
Sorry, I changed my mind. Never play this game if you don't have at least 8 hour per each day, or find some mods that optimize your time significantly.

Overhaul mods to try:
- The Last Days Of Third Age(aka Lords of the Rings)
- Native Gold Edition(Same shit as native but has some improvements and new mechanics)

Please, suggest me a mods to fix my pain in the ass with this game.
Thanks.
The term game over can apply.  hitting a game over and the company tries to get you to keep playing. stupid

Game refuses to launch. Steam says the game is running. Task manager shows it's background processes running. Screen and taskbar show absolutely nothing. Complete waste of time. Not only does the game refuse to launch, it refuses to close as well requiring a system restart to stop the game from hold your PC hostage. Avoid like the plague.

Honestly, M&B warband is fking garbage, its base game is incredibly shallow, the only redeeming quality is its mods that it's had over the years, i recommend you play its viking conquest dlc, or bannerlord instead, but if you really want to delve into a 15 year old game's mods, which if you do, i recommend trying out The Last Days of the Third Age, and Prophesy of Pendor, idk whether to give it a positive review, or negative review, so ill just give it a negative cause the base game sucks assssssss.

mount and blade warband is another textbook example why you shouldnt go to reddit.com to get your video game opinions. this game is awful, not fun and every room and town is copy pasted. looks worse than poop like pubg or even super mario 64 everything. awful gameplay. all you do is run letters to idiots on horseback (just email them like cmon)and then you get like 5 ingame dollars and a pat on the back even though you had to kill 30 idiot bad guys that want to kill you for no reason. then you are a day late and the kings wanna lynch you and expel you from the city and wander around with no friends just like in real life. if you like this its beacuse you a probably a fat redditor with no meaningful relationship in your life*

Don't see how people say this is better than Bannerlord. AI is dogwater, combat is garbage, relations, diplomacy, renown system, all terrible. Mods do not improve the experience. Props on some teams that have recreated cool worlds but apart from that, dogshit game, dogshit mods, dogshit experience.
The turks stole this game from a white man and claimed it as their own
feels like an alpha version, every system is shallow and emtly
no real non fag would play this game
It should not end so quickly.
Not good.
lol.

Mount & Blade: Warband is not a bad video game. For a certain type of person who enjoys this wargaming genre, it might be one of the best games ever made. Yet, I find it hard to recommend. It's not so much that some graphics have aged, as the game still looks pretty good. For a game with this much text, I think they could've spent a little bit more time making it readable and well-aligned, but I don't think that's a fatal flaw either. 

Rather, I just find that there isn't that much detail worth thinking about. Lords, cities, the shape of the continent, your companions and more are so generic they might as well be randomly generated. There are a handful of quests which I can almost see how they were programmed in my head. Battles degenerate into swinging around the enemy and attacking from the back or just spamming your attack. The whole game has a feeling of being a fisher-price version of what it wants to be.

Another thing lowering my opinion on the game is its cost. Right now Warband is going for $19.99, despite being over 15 years old. Of course, you can wait for it to go on sale, but for a game this old it's probably about time to permanently drop the price so the developers can go below the 90% sale limit. 

So I can't recommend it. Maybe if you get it for 2$ on a huge sale and you don't really value your time very much, or if this type of game is really your thing you'll love it, otherwise it's kinda forgettable.

Played both Warband and Bannerlord.
In this game you will see 90%-95% of the content from Bannerlord, but with less bugs, less grind and less frustration.
You can jump from 150 to 500 battle size limit by changing the config file.

In the Bannerlord there is only one "good" feature, it is when you can call other lords from the distance to join your party for influence, but unfortunately even this important feature does not work well in the sequel(lords getting captured on the way or losing whole their army because of starving on the way to you).

Anyway this game is still lucks Quality of life features, has a lot of micromanagement in the UI, quests is just boring, repetitive and what I really hate is how you pushed to do that quests because you need to build relationships with lords which will take you weeks or months of playing. Without building relationships you are not able to progress the game further, but this mechanic really sucks. Oh, you even need to build relationships with f*cking villages, because in other case they will not give higher grade troops.
